Description: Hematite cylinder seal; a bearded, kilted figure (priest?), wearing a pointed, panelled hat, with his hair in a queue, stands in the royal posture behind the suppliant goddess and a deity in a flounced robe with hands clasped; they face a bearded sun(?) god in a flounced robe who holds a sun god's knife beneath a star-disc and crescent; behind him is a goddess in a flounced robe (full-face) who holds out one hand towards him. In the field are a fly above a fish; a ball-and-staff; a hedgehog above a monkey; the motifs in the lower field are crudely cut; worn and chipped; there has been an attempt to mask the chip above the head of the principal god.
Bibliographic references: Collon 1986a / Catalogue of the Western Asiatic Seals in the British Museum: Cylinder Seals III: Isin-Larsa and Old Babylonian Periods (356)
Leichty E et al 1988a / Catalogue of the Babylonian Tablets in the British Museum, volume VIII: Tablets from Sippar 3 (p.300)
Acquisition name: From: Sir Ernest A T Wallis Budge
